contentrichtext.text: {{italictitle}} {{Taxobox | name = ''Zyzomys'' | image = Zyzomys_pedunculatus.jpg | image_caption = The [[Central Rock Rat]] (''Zyzomys pedunculatus'') | fossil_range = [[Pleistocene]]? - Recent | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammal]]ia | ordo = [[Rodent]]ia | superfamilia = [[Muroidea]] | familia = [[Muridae]] | subfamilia = [[Murinae]] | genus = '''''Zyzomys''''' | genus_authority = [[Oldfield Thomas|Thomas]], 1909 | subdivision_ranks = Species | subdivision = ''[[Zyzomys argurus]]''<br> ''[[Zyzomys maini]]''<br> ''[[Zyzomys palatilis]]''<br> ''[[Zyzomys pedunculatus]]''<br> ''[[Zyzomys woodwardi]]'' }} '''''Zyzomys''''' is a [[genus]] of [[rodent]]s with unusually thick, long [[tail]]s. Five [[species]] of the [[genus]] are known in [[Australia]], where they are called rock rats or '''thick-tailed rats'''. They were discovered by [[Oldfield Thomas|Michael Rogers Oldfield Thomas]] in 1909. ==Taxonomy== There are five known species of rock-rat. The Central Rock Rat (''Zyzomys pedunculatus'') was once believed to be extinct until rediscovered in 1996. *[[Silver-Tailed Rock Rat]], ''Zyzomys argurus'' *[[Arnhem Land Rock Rat]], ''Zyzomys maini'' *[[Carpentarian Rock Rat]], ''Zyzomys palatilis'' *[[Central Rock Rat]], ''Zyzomys pedunculatus'' *[[Kimberley Rock Rat]], ''Zyzomys woodwardi'' ==References== *Musser, G. G. and M. D. Carleton. 2005. Superfamily Muroidea. Pp. 894-1531 ''in'' Mammal Species of the World a Taxonomic and Geographic Reference. D. E. Wilson and D. M. Reeder eds. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore. {{Murinae|P.}} [[Category:Old World rats and mice]]
